words.etymology_text: After the lake, uta- + järvi, in which the first component may be akin to utu or to Inari Sami uuđâs (“new”).

words.etymology_text: From Proto-Finnic *udar, most likely borrowed from an Indo-Iranian language, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *h₁ówHdʰr̥ (“udder”). Compare Sanskrit ऊधर् (ūdhar). Cognate to Estonian udar (“udder”), Livvi udareh (“udder”), Erzya одар (odar, “udder”), and Eastern Mari водар (vodar, “udder”).

words.etymology_text: From New Latin Utopia, the name of a fictional island, possessing a seemingly perfect socio-politico-legal system in the book Utopia (1516) by Sir Thomas More. Coined from Ancient Greek οὐ (ou, “not, no”) + τόπος (tópos, “place, region”).
From Proto-Finnic *utu, probably borrowed from Proto-Germanic [Term?] (compare Icelandic úði (“drizzle”)).
